titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Roundell Tristram Toke diaries and photographs from military service in China and Japan, 1900-1907 RL.11647
titlestmt.author: Paula Jeannet

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-12-19 21:44:58 UTC.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Roundell Tristram Toke diaries and photographs from military service in China and Japan
did.abstract: Collection comprises diaries and photographs by British officer Roundell Tristram Toke, documenting in detail his military service in China and Japan during the Boxer Rebellion and Russo-Japanese War, 1900 to 1907. The first diary is set in China; the other three in Japan. All four contain daily descriptions of weather, social and administrative activities, military engagements, rations, medical training, diplomacy, and other details, with some sketches of formations and drill patterns. The diaries are accompanied by approximately 145 photographs from China and Japan, with images of military camps, drills, equipment, engagements, destroyed areas, Russian war prisoners and their camps, towns, landscapes, harbors, a few social gatherings, and civilians. The collection also includes Toke's leather cigar case, inscribed on the inside with his postings with dates, beginning with Weihai, China, 1900.
did.physdesc: Four diaries; leather case; approximately 145 photographs.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Roundell Tristram Toke, who signed his diaries "R.T. Toke," was born in Crewkerne, Somerset, November 9, 1869. He was a British officer, first serving in 1888 in the 4th Battalion, Devonshire Regiment, then in the Welsh Regiment, Chinese Regiment, 1892, rising in rank to Lieutenant Colonel by 1916. In addition to his military service in China and Japan, he served in World War I from 1914-1918, commanding the 6th Battalion, Bedfordshire Regiment, from August 24, 1915-May 3, 1916. Toke died November 23, 1957, in Kent.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: After the Russian Empire leased Port Arthur from China for 25 years in March 1898, the United Kingdom pressured the Chinese government into leasing Wei-hai-wei as anchorage for the Royal Navy's China Station and a port of call for ships of the Royal Navy in the Far East. To protect the British interests, a British army regiment was formed consisting of Chinese rank and file under British officers. Among those officers was Captain Toke of the Welsh Regiment, the author of the diaries and the photographer who created the images in this collection.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. A small group of rolled photographs are slated for conservation treatment and are temporarily closed to access.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Roundell Tristram Toke diaries and photographs were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2018.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Roundell Tristram Toke diaries and photographs, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed and encoded by Paula Jeannet, July 2018.
Accession(s) represented in this collection guide: 2018-0072.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related collection: Friedrich Carl Peetz photographs, 1900, Rubenstein Library, Duke University.
Related collection: William Hillman Shockley photographs, 1896-1922 and undated, bulk 1897-1909, Rubenstein Library, Duke University.
Related collection: M. F. Wilson diary, 1903 September 21-1904 September 20, Rubenstein Library, Duke University.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: Collection comprises autograph manuscript diaries and photographs of British officer Roundell Tristram Toke, during his service in China and Japan during the Boxer Rebellion and Russo-Japanese War, 1900 to 1907. The diaries contain daily descriptions of weather, social and administrative activities, regiment training and drills, military engagements, rations, Japanese prisoner of war camps for the Russians, medical training, foreign diplomacy, and other details. Some contain sketches of formations and drill patterns. The first diary, from 1900, describes service in China during the Boxer Rebellion, while the last three, January 1905-November 1907, detail his service in Japan as an attache` at the British Embassy in Tokyo and military consultant to the Japanese during and after the Russo-Japanese War.

Toke's diaries are accompanied by approximately 145 photographs: 40 unmounted larger albumen and 105 smaller silver gelatin prints. These images vividly document his time in China and Japan, showing military camps, officers, drills, engagements, landmark battle and burial sites such as 203 Metre Hill, Russian prisoners and their camp, towns, harbors, destroyed railroads and buildings, and Chinese and Japanese civilians. There are a few more personal photos of Western women, children, and men. A series of larger images from China depict the destruction and death caused by the conflict of 1900.
The collection includes Toke's leather cigar case, inscribed on the inside with his postings with dates, beginning with Wei-Hai-Wei in China, 1900.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Roundell Tristram Toke's personal narratives of his military service in China and Japan take the form of three bound commercial daily diaries and one disbound diary, housed in two custom boxes. A leather cigar case is with the diaries.
The first volume dates from January through December 1900, and recounts Toke's service in China during the Boxer Rebellion.

After his service in China, Captain Toke was transferred to Japan, serving as a military attaché at the British Embassy in Tokyo, evidently tasked with serving as a military advisor to the Japanese with a particular emphasis on artillery matters. The signing of the Anglo-Japanese Alliance in 1902 and the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904 led to increased cooperation between the Japanese and British military.
The other three daily diaries relate to this period, describing his military and diplomatic activities in Japan in 1905, 1906, and 1907.

Included with Toke's diaries are approximately 145 loose photographs (including some duplicates) taken by him in this period, including military camps, landscapes, civilians, war scenes, and Russian prisoners of war in their camps. Many are captioned in his hand. The photographs are described in a separate series in this collection guide.

physdesc.extent: In custom box with two other volumes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One bound commercial diary filled with almost daily entries by Toke, detailing his service in China during the Boxer Rebellion. The life of an officer at the camp Wei-hai-wei included much dining, sightseeing, and playing sports, until Chinese anti-colonial militias began their violent uprising. In March 1900, Toke writes of dispersing unlawful assemblies in neighboring villages, followed by battles to put down the rebellion, and scenes of destruction, with dead and wounded soldiers as well as many civilians. Included with this diary are approximately 40 photographs of China, many depicting the destruction relating to the rebellion. Many of the images are captioned in pencil on verso, evidently at a later date.

physdesc.extent: In custom box with one other volume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two bound commercial diaries, filled with almost daily entries recounting Toke's service as an attaché to the British Embassy in Tokyo. Besides numerous entries concerning the weather, his travel within Japan, his dining companions (including notable government officials and nobility), and living arrangements, he also includes some insights into military matters (including details relating to the Battle of Mukden), although does not appear to have seen any action himself.

Included in the rear of the diaries are listings of various financial accounts. Attached in some capacity to the Japanese Army during the Russo-Japanese War, he was decorated by the Japanese for his assistance and was involved in transporting captured Russian guns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Disbound but with the original upper wrapper present, this 212-page diary covers a brief period following the Russo-Japanese War in which Toke was attached to the 1st Regiment of Imperial Guard at Takehashi Barracks. His detailed observations concern the military maneuvers and exercises of the regiment, as well as their outfitting, arms, daily rations, and organization. He also comments on social gatherings and individuals he meets.

Illustrated with many sketches of military formations and maneuvers, and with two mounted photographs showing troops on a firing range. A few official handwritten letters sent to Toke (including several from a Captain Saito), are mounted on the pages.
Original paper cover bears label with Toke's name and location, and handwritten title: "Diary during attachment to 1st Regiment of Guards, Tokio."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Approximately 40 rolled photographs are closed until conservation treatment is completed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains over 140 photographs taken by Roundell Tristram Toke while he was in military service in China (1900) and Japan (1905-1907). A small group of approximately 40 photographs taken in China are larger in size and may be unmounted albumen prints.

The 103 loose photographs in this group are all early gelatin silver prints measuring 3x4 inches with some minor variations. The earliest are contact prints. Judging from the two envelopes marked with Captain Toke's name, the developing was done by the Kusakabe Kimbei studio in Tokyo or Yokohama. The first prints in this group are four hand-colored photographs of three geishas and a garden; although the size and similarity of these to the other photographs indicate they may have been taken by Toke, the hand-tinting may be the work of the Kimbei studio. Also present in the first few photographs is a small full-length standing portrait of Lieutenant Colonel Toke in dress uniform.

A small group of approximately 40 photographs taken in China are larger in size and may be unmounted albumen prints. They are tightly rolled and in the Conservation lab; closed pending completion of treatment.

scopecontent.head: Description
scopecontent.p: Dalny was the Russian name for a port town in northeastern China on the Liaodong Peninsula; in Japanese it became known as Dalian or Ta-lien, and Darien. Now known as Dalian (Liaoning Sheng, China).

scopecontent.p: Probably Narashino, where other photographs were taken. Narashino (習志野市 Narashino-shi) is a city located in Chiba Prefecture, Japan. It was the site of a prisoner of war camp built during the Russo-Japanese War.

scopecontent.head: Description
scopecontent.p: Probably Narashino, where other photographs were taken. Narashino (習志野市 Narashino-shi) is a city located in Chiba Prefecture, Japan. It was the site of a prisoner of war camp built during the Russo-Japanese War.

scopecontent.head: Description
scopecontent.p: Weihaiwei, or Weihai, as it is now known, is a seaport city in northeastern China, Shandong Province.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Taken in China, these unmounted albumen photographs show scenes associated with the Boxer Rebellion and its aftermath. The prints are larger than the other photographs in the collection.
